usageNotes: Changes from one type of a political system to another (e.g. from military dictatorship to multiparty democracy), as well as less comprehensive institutional changes that nevertheless modify the rules of the game (e.g. political party laws, electoral laws, powers and functions of different branches) are coded here.
examples: <source>President Dos Sontas</source> has reportedly <verb>conceded</verb> at last to demands from <target>National Union for the Total Independence of Angola</target> (UNITA) to <verb>overhaul</verb> the <verb>judiciary</verb>.
<source>Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril</source> <verb>resigned</verb> yesterday to <verb>allow</verb> <target>Haiti_s</target> <verb>first democratic elections</verb> to take place.
exampleNotes: The political change in this lead is more fundamental than leadership change given the mention of ``first__ democratic elections, which points to  potential change in the overall political system (i.e. democratization).

name: Return, release, not specified below
description: All acts of releasing or returning not otherwise specified.
usageNotes: This category contains sub-forms for more detailed coding whenever possible.
examples: According to a zoo spokesperson <source>Malaysian authorities</source> have <verb>initiated</verb> the process of <verb>returning</verb> the four baby <verb>gorillas</verb> to <target>Nigeria</target>, amid speculations they were illegally captured in the wild.

name: Return, release persons
description: Release people, including prisoners and hostages, from detention or arrest.
usageNotes: Formal pardons, amnesties, commutations, and exchanges of prisoners should all be coded here.
examples: <source>Polish police</source> today <verb>released</verb> the <verb>correspondent</verb> of the <target>American news agency United Press International</target>, who was detained for 23 hours and questioned in connection with an inquiry into alleged illegal activities.
<source>Bosnian Serb forces</source> Tuesday <verb>let free</verb> six <target>French UN peacekeepers</target> held captive inside a UN armored personnel carrier since Friday, a UN spokesman said.

name: Return, release property
description: Return or release previously controlled, confiscated property, including land.
usageNotes: When confiscated property or other rights are not returned but compensation is provided instead, those incidents should be coded as 080.
examples: <source>French maritime</source> authorities today <verb>release</verb> an impounded <verb>ship</verb> operated by the <target>Greenpeace</target> ecology movement, port officials said.

An <source>Egyptian court</source> <verb>released</verb> a <target>Lebanese</target> millionaire_s <verb>assets</verb> of nearly 19 million dollars on Saturday six years after they were frozen in a major bank scandal.

name: Ease economic sanction, boycott, or embargo
description: Lift, relax, or lessen economic sanctions, boycott, embargoes, or penalties.
usageNotes: Use this event form to code state activities that imply easing of limitations to normal economic relations.
examples: <source>Germany</source> on Wednesday <verb>lifted sanctions</verb> against <verb>gold</verb> from <target>South Africa</target> in recognition of the country_s moves to abolish apartheid, a government spokesman said.
The <source>United Arab Emirates</source> (UAE) has <verb>lifted</verb> its <verb>boycott</verb> of <verb>trade</verb> in oil on <target>Namibia</target>, effective since March 31.

The <source>European Union</source> <verb>failed</verb> Wednesday <verb>to renew sanctions</verb> against <target>Zimbabwe</target>, with the fate of an EU-Africa summit scheduled for April hanging in the balance.

name: Allow international involvement, not specified below
description: Allow entry of or intervention by international actors not further specified.
usageNotes: Use the following sub-categories whenever possible. The types of international involvement covered in this category require physical access to territories under the source_s control. Note that accepting international involvement in the form of mediation is coded under 04. The target should be the international actor whose involvement is allowed or received.
examples: <source>Kyrgyz Prime Minister Nikolai Tanaev</source> <verb>received</verb> a mission of <verb>observers</verb> from the <target>OSCE</target>, informing them in detail on the economic situation of the country.

name: Receive deployment of peacekeepers
description: Allow, receive peacekeeping forces in territories controlled by the source.
usageNotes: Code here reported deployment of peacekeeping forces (with location of deployment as the source); mere promises or agreements by fighting parties or a country to accept deployment of peacekeeping forces in its territories should be coded as 0355, and commitments to provide peacekeepers should be coded as 0334. The target for an 084 event should be the actor providing the peacekeepers. Note that this event form is accompanied by the linked event `Provide military protection or peacekeeping_ (074).
examples: A first patch of <target>Bangladeshi</target> <verb>peacekeeping</verb> troops <verb>arrived</verb> in <source>Sierra Leone</source> Tuesday, joining 12 unarmed military observers as the first element of an 800-strong Bangladeshi contingent due here, U.N. officials said.
exampleNotes: Two linked events (0861 and 074) are coded with actors reversed.

name: Receive inspectors
description: Allow, receive inspectors in territories controlled by the source actor.
usageNotes: Code here reported deployment or arrival of inspectors; mere promises or agreements to accept their deployment should be coded as 0355 instead. The target for an 085 event should be the inspectors or the country/agency providing them. This event form is typically accompanied by code under category 09.
examples: The <target>IAEA</target> has <verb>dispatched inspectors to</verb> Esfahan Uranium Conversion Facilities (UCF) in central <source>Iran</source> to monitor resumption of peaceful nuclear work at the plant.
exampleNotes: Two linked events (0862 and 090) are coded with actors reversed.

name: Allow for humanitarian access
description: Allow access to, receive humanitarian agencies in territories controlled by the source actor.
usageNotes: Mere promises to allow such access should be coded as 0355. Note that this event form is accompanied by the linked event `Provide humanitarian aid_ (073) if the target is the humanitarian agency; in some cases the target would be the particular area that is given access.
examples: <verb>Humanitarian access</verb> for the <target>Darfur</target> region has <verb>improved</verb> significantly since September as the <source>Khartoum government</source> tried to secure international favor.

<source>Uzbekistan</source> finally <verb>opened</verb> the Friendship Bridge after four years <verb>to allow</verb> the delivery of 1,000 tons of <verb>grain and flour to</verb> <target>Afghanistan</target>, where millions of people are at risk of starvation as winter sets in, reports aid agencies.

name: De-escalate military engagement, not specified below
description: Concede militarily, stop fighting, or take measures to ease military conflict or tension not further specified.
usageNotes: Use sub-categories for more detailed coding whenever possible. Note that only real manifestations of de-escalation are coded here, expressions of intent to de-escalate are not.

name: Declare truce, ceasefire
description: Declare or observe truce or ceasefire to interrupt fighting.
usageNotes: Although mere declarations of ceasefire, or agreements to commence a ceasefire, do not guarantee that military engagement is actually halted, they are still coded here. The target could be the location for the ceasefire or the opponent.
examples: The <source>pro-Iranian Hizbollah</source> (Party of God) group <verb>declared</verb> a unilateral <verb>ceasefire</verb> on Wednesday in <target>south Lebanon</target> after 12 days of battles with the Syrian-backed Amal militia.

name: Ease military blockade
description: Lessen or halt use of armed (military, police, or security) forces to seal off a territory to prevent exit or entry of goods and/or people.
examples: The <source>Israeli army</source> <verb>lifted</verb> Friday a day-old <verb>blockade</verb> on <target>Palestinian</target> lorries passing through this crossing point between the Gaza Strip and the Jewish state, officials told AFP.

name: Demobilize armed forces
description: Hand over or otherwise reduce or eliminate arms, weapons; discharge soldiers or other armed personnel.
usageNotes: The source actor for this event is the demobilizing party; the target is either the party against whom the source was formerly fighting or the actor to whom weaponry is turned in.
examples: One third of <source>ethnic Albanian guerrillas</source> operating in <target>Macedonia</target> have been <verb>demobilized</verb> since the August 13 peace accord between Macedonian and ethnic Albanian political parties, two rebel commanders told AFP by phone Sunday.

name: Retreat or surrender militarily
description: Retreat, withdraw, yield control of a location or territory by pulling out armed forces.
usageNotes: Note that the yielding should involve a comprehensive military disengagement, at least from a certain area of contention.
examples: Five hundred <source>Ugandan rebels</source> <verb>surrendered</verb> last week in the eastern <verb>town</verb> in <target>Soroti</target> followin a government offensive in the area, a local official said.

The <source>United States</source> <verb>speeded</verb> up the <verb>withdrawal</verb> of some <verb>invasion</verb> forces from <target>Panama</target> on Wednesday, but defence officials cautioned that no deadline had been set for complete removal of the troops.
<source>Bosnian Serbs</source> said on Tuesday their forces had <verb>completed</verb> their <verb>withdrawal</verb> from the beseiged <target>Bosnian town of Gorazde</target>.

name: Investigate, not specified below
description: All non-covert investigations not otherwise specified.
usageNotes: This residual category is not coded except when distinctions among codes 091-094 cannot be made. Also note that category 09 should be used only when investigations are being or have been carried out. Investigation of historical cases should also be coded here.
examples: The <source>United Nations</source> <verb>has sent</verb> 21 military and civilian personnel to <target>Yugoslavia</target> on Wednesday to <verb>investigate</verb> the feasibility of a 10,000-member peacekeeping force, a U.N. spokesman said on Monday.

name: Investigate crime, corruption
description: Question or inquire criminal (theft, killing, etc) or corruption cases.
examples: <source>Judge Alejandro Rivera</source> <verb>opened fraud investigations</verb> against 28 <target>Chilean government officials</target> suspected of taking kickbacks, the court said Friday.

A <target>US national</target> <verb>has been put under investigation</verb> in <source>Italy</source> <verb>for</verb> her possible role in <verb>rioting</verb> during a G8 summit in Genoa last month, Ansa news agency reported.

name: Investigate human rights abuses
description: Inquire or search into human rights abuses such as rape, torture, targeted assassinations, and violations of basic freedoms.
usageNotes: Investigations of war crimes are coded as 094 instead. Alleged or potential perpetrators should be coded as targets.
examples: Members of the <source>Association of African Jurists</source>, a body linked to the Organization of African Unity, <verb>investigated</verb> <verb>welfare</verb> of nearly 2,000 <target>Libyans</target>, some of whom have been held as long as seven years.

<source>Israel</source>_s high court <verb>opened</verb> a landmark <verb>hearing</verb> Wednesday into the legality of secret <verb>interrogation techniques</verb> used against <target>Palestinian</target> detainees.

name: Investigate military action
description: Inquire or search into military activities such as violations of ceasefire, seizures, and invasions.
usageNotes: If military actions in question involve potential human rights violations or war crimes specifically, code them as 092 or 094 instead. The perpetrator of the questionable military action should be coded as the target.
examples: The <source>Ceasefire Violations Committee</source> (CFVC) has <verb>completed</verb> its <verb>investigation</verb> into an allegation by the Liberian Peace Council (LPC) <verb>that</verb> the <target>NPFL</target> had <verb>taken over</verb> the city of Greenville.

name: Investigate war crimes
description: Inquire or investigate potential war crimes or look into allegations of war crimes.
usageNotes: If the question surrounding a military action is not specified to be potential war crimes, 093 should be used instead. The perpetrator of the questionable military action should be coded as the target.
examples: <source>Croatia</source> is <verb>investigating</verb> alleged <verb>war crimes</verb> by <target>Croatian extremists</target> against Serb civilians and prisoners and will bring suspects to trial, a Croatian official said.

<source>Serbian military police</source> have <verb>launched</verb> an <verb>investigation</verb> into alleged <verb>crimes</verb> committed by <target>Croat forces</target> against ethnic Serb civilians and Montenegrin prisoners of war <verb>during</verb> the 1991-1995 Serbo-Croatian <verb>conflict</verb>, the newspaper Jutarnji list reported Thursday.

name: Demand, not specified below
description: All demands and orders not otherwise specified.
usageNotes: This residual category is not coded except when distinctions among codes 101-108 cannot be made. Note that demands are stronger or more forceful and potentially carry more serious repercussions---although not as much as threats---than simple appeals. We rely primarily on the language used by reporters to make this distinction. All demands are verbal acts.
examples: <source>Poland_s parliament</source> has <verb>demanded</verb> an immediate admission by <target>Moscow</target> that Soviet NKVD security forces murdered more than 15,000 captive Polish officers during World War Two.

name: Demand material cooperation, not specified below
description: Require, demand that target engages in some form of material exchange.
usageNotes: Use the following sub-categories whenever possible. Demands for judicial cooperation, such as extradition of criminals, or compliance with requirements of an investigation are coded here.
examples: <source>French President Jacques Chirac</source> <verb>issued</verb> a stern reminder Saturday to <target>Iraq</target> that it <verb>must cooperate</verb> fully <verb>with</verb> UN <verb>inspectors</verb> probing suspect sites for weapons of mass destruction.

An <source>Argentine judge</source> has <verb>ordered</verb> former president <target>Carlos Menem</target> to appear October 16 for <verb>questioning</verb> in an investigation of illegal arms sales to Croatia and Ecuador in the 1990s, court sources said Wednesday.

name: Demand economic cooperation
description: Require, demand that target engages in economic exchange or expands such ties.
usageNotes: Use this code for demands for economic activities such as trade and investment. Demands for provision of economic aid---not mutual exchange---are coded as 1031 instead.
examples: The <source>Bush administration</source> <verb>declared</verb> Tuesday that <target>China</target> <verb>must drop barriers</verb> to U.S. <verb>exports</verb> or face tariff penalties for maintaining unfair trade practices.

name: Demand military cooperation
description: Require, demand that target engages in or expands military relations.
usageNotes: Use this code for demands that target engages in military cooperation, such as through joint exercises or weapon sales. Demands for provision of military aid---not mutual exchange---are coded as 1032 instead.
examples: The <source>PRC</source> on Tuesday <verb>demanded</verb> that the <target>US</target> <verb>cancel</verb> plans to <verb>sell</verb> air-to-surface anti-tank <verb>weapons</verb> to Taiwan to avoid ``new damage__ to US-PRC relations.
exampleNotes: While the requested policy does not directly involve material exchange between the source and the target, the former is clearly demanding cooperation on military issues.

name: Demand judicial cooperation
description: Require, demand that target engages in or expands cooperation in judicial matters.
usageNotes: Use this code for demands that target engages in judicial cooperation, such as through extraditing wanted individuals.
examples: A senior <source>British minister</source> <verb>reiterated</verb> that <target>Libya</target> <verb>must hand over alleged</verb> bombers of the U.S. airliner as he embarked on a trip to North Africa to seek Arab support for the demand.

name: Demand intelligence cooperation
description: Require, demand that target exchanges intelligence or information.
usageNotes: Use this code for demands that target engages in intelligence cooperation, including but not limited to the exchange of information in security matters.
examples: The rebel <source>Kurdistan Workers_ Party</source> <verb>issued</verb> a declaration <verb>demanding</verb> that the <target>Turkish government</target> provide <verb>information</verb> on the safety of its leader Abdullah Ocalan.

name: Demand for diplomatic cooperation (such as policy support)
description: Require, demand expansion of diplomatic ties or cooperation.
usageNotes: This code refers to demands for expanded diplomatic ties and non-tangible support on particular policies. Demands for more specific forms of diplomacy, such as mediation and negotiation are coded elsewhere within category 10.
examples: <source>Kosovo Municipality Association</source> (AKK) officials <verb>demanded support from</verb> the <target>Kosovo Assembly</target> in regaining control over the properties that belonged to them before.

<source>Greece</source> bluntly <verb>demanded</verb> that its <target>European Community</target> partners <verb>refuse to recognize</verb> the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, on Greece_s northern border, as long as it keeps that name.
<source>Palestinian officials</source> <verb>demanded</verb> Friday that the <target>United States</target> match the European Union_s <verb>support</verb> for Palestinian <verb>statehood</verb>.

name: Demand material aid, not specified below
description: Require, demand provision of material assistance not otherwise specified.
usageNotes: This category contains sub-forms for more detailed coding whenever possible. The source could be demanding aid for itself or on behalf of a third party; in either case, the actor who is expected to provide assistance should be coded as the target.
examples: The <source>Third World Water Forum</source> <verb>concluded</verb> on Saturday that the <target>US</target> and other developed nations <verb>must allocate</verb> greater financial <verb>resources to help</verb> with the battle against the global water and sanitation crisis.

name: Demand economic aid
description: Require, demand provision of economic assistance.
usageNotes: This event form is typically, although not exclusively, a verbal act. Demands for 	extit{loans or debt relief} are also coded here. Demands for reciprocal economic exchange, such as trade, should be coded as 1011 instead.
examples: According to reports the <source>UK</source> is <verb>pushing hard</verb> for the <target>US</target> <verb>support</verb> its <verb>debt relief</verb> plan to tackle poverty in Africa.

name: Demand military aid
description: Require, demand provision of military assistance.
usageNotes: Note that demands for military security and deployment of peacekeepers are coded as 1034 instead.

name: Demand humanitarian aid
description: Require, demand provision of humanitarian aid.
usageNotes: Demands by refugees to be let into the territories of other countries (which should be coded as targets) and asylum demands all fit here. These are not necessarily verbal acts; refugees could be actively seeking shelter or refuge in target countries or regions.
examples: Some 800,000 <source>Iraqi Kurds</source> <verb>sought refuge</verb> in <target>Germany</target> last month.

name: Demand military protection or peacekeeping
description: Require, demand that the target provides military protection or peacekeeping forces.
usageNotes: The source that demands peacekeepers could demand that for itself or on behalf of another party.
examples: <source>Ethnic Albanians in south Serbia</source> are <verb>demanding</verb> a <target>U.N.</target> military presence to <verb>protect</verb> them against a heavily armed ruling Serb minority and prevent a Bosnia-style civil war, but some foreign monitors are skeptical.

The <source>Red Cross operating in Iraq</source> <verb>said</verb> <target>US</target> and <target>British forces</target> <verb>must ensure security</verb> to allow emergency water, food, and medical supplies to reach the needy.
exampleNotes: Two events are coded due to the compound target.

name: Demand political reform, not specified below
description: Require, demand political change not otherwise specified.
usageNotes: This event form refers to verbal and non-threatening appeals. Demands that take the form of demonstrations, protests, etc. are coded under category 14 instead. Source actors can be local citizens as well as international actors; they could be making the appeal on their own behalf or on behalf of others. Note that when the requested reform clearly constitutes some form of concession or yielding by the target, such as the easing of administrative sanctions, a more appropriate ``Demand__ code might be found under 105.
examples: At the end of a seminar on reform, around 100 <source>Arab intellectuals and activists</source> <verb>published</verb> a declaration <verb>demanding</verb> wide-ranging <verb>political changes</verb> in the <target>Arab world</target>.

name: Demand leadership change
description: Require, demand change in leadership or power.
usageNotes: This event form refers to verbal and non-threatening appeals. Demands that take the form of demonstrations, protests, etc. are coded under category 14 instead. Note that even though demands for the target to resign or relinquish power are forms of yielding, they are still coded here. Also code demands for elections here (unless they are first-time elections and hence constitute major institutional change).
examples: <source>Sunnis</source> have <verb>demanded</verb> that <verb>control of</verb> the Interior <verb>Ministry</verb> be taken away from <target>Shiite religious parties</target> in the next government.

<source>Rwandan rebels</source> <verb>demanded</verb> the <verb>removal of President</verb> <target>Juvenal Habyariman</target> and his ruling party at the fourth round of talks aimed at ending a 23-month civil war.

Former Socialist prime minister <source>Andreas Papandreou</source> <verb>demanded</verb> immediate <verb>elections</verb> after a special court cleared him of all charges in <target>Greece</target>_s biggest corruption trial this century.

name: Demand policy change
description: Require, demand change in any particular policy.
usageNotes: This event form refers to verbal and non-threatening demands. Demands that take the form of demonstrations, protests, etc. are coded under category 14 instead. Just like the source actor, the policy in question can also be domestic or international in nature. If it is clear from the lead that by demanding certain policy changes the source is in fact demanding that the target yield or concede, the event might be better coded under 105 (e.g. demands for military withdrawal should be coded as 1056).
examples: <source>Opposition groups in Zimbabwe</source> are <verb>demanding</verb> that <target>President Mugabe</target> <verb>abandon</verb> his controversial <verb>policy</verb> of land confiscations.

name: Demand rights
description: Require, demand provision or expansion of social, political, or other rights.
usageNotes: This event form refers to verbal and non-threatening demands. Demands that take the form of demonstrations, protests, etc. are coded under category 14 instead. If it is clear from the lead that by demanding certain rights the source is in fact demanding that the target yield or concede, the event might be better coded under 105. Demands for provision of compensation for previously violated rights, for instance, are coded as 105.
examples: The main <source>Hutu rebel group</source>, Forces for Defence of Democracy (FDD), insisted on its <verb>demands</verb> that <target>Burundi_s government grant</target> the Hutu majority more <verb>rights</verb>.

name: Demand change in institutions, regime
description: Require, demand major institutional, constitutional, or regime change.
usageNotes: This event form refers to verbal and non-threatening demands. Demands that take the form of demonstrations, protests, etc. are coded under category 14 instead. Institutional change is different from policy change in that the former directly alters the rules of the game. Demands for fundamental changes in the political system (e.g. democratization) as well as more limited institutional changes (e.g. changing electoral law) are coded here.
examples: <source>Rwandan rebels</source> <verb>announced</verb> that <target>President Kagame</target> and his <target>Rwandan Patriotic Front</target> <verb>must agree</verb> to major <verb>constitutional changes</verb> before they demobilize.
The <source>Albanians of southern Serbia</source> are <verb>demanding</verb> political and territorial <verb>autonomy</verb> from <target>Serbian authorities</target>.

name: Demand that target yield, not specified below
description: Require, demand that target yields or concedes, not otherwise specified.
usageNotes: This event form is typically, although not exclusively, a verbal act. The source for this event type may or may not be one of the adversaries; a third party could also be demanding that one or more of the parties in conflict (who are coded as targets) to yield. When a threat is attached to a demand for yielding, the appropriate code under category 13 should be used instead. Also, if accompanied by some form of protest activity, codes under category 14 should be used. When yielding actually takes place, use the appropriate code under category 08.
examples: The <source>United States</source> on Thursday <verb>demanded</verb> that the <target>Democratic People_s Republic of Korea</target> (DPRK) <verb>forsake</verb> its nuclear <verb>program</verb>.
exampleNotes: Because no military engagement has yet occurred, this default code is used instead of 1056.

name: Demand easing of administrative sanctions
description: Require, demand that target relaxes administrative restrictions.
usageNotes: Use this code when a government is pushed to undertake some political changes that clearly constitute some form of concession or yielding, such as relaxing or removing bans, curfews, or other restrictions that are already in place. Demands that take the form of demonstrations, protests, etc. are coded under category 14 instead.
examples: Human rights organization <source>Amnesty International</source> <verb>demanded</verb> that the <target>Sudanese government</target> <verb>end curbs</verb> on <verb>press freedom</verb>.

The <source>International Labor Office</source> (ILO) <verb>reiterated</verb> its <verb>demand</verb> today that <target>Israel</target> <verb>ease restrictions</verb> on the <verb>movement</verb> of Palestinian workers.

name: Demand easing of political dissent
description: Require, demand that target stops political protest activities.
usageNotes: Use this code for demands that the target stop engaging in protests, demonstrations, strikes, etc. Note that this code refers exclusively to verbal demands; if the source actively seeks to stop activities through repressive measures, 175 is used instead.
examples: <source>Iranian authorities</source> have been <verb>pressuring</verb> <target>workers of the United Bus Company of Tehran</target> (Sharekat-e Vahed) <verb>to cancel</verb> the <verb>strike</verb> they have been planning for better pay and working conditions.

name: Demand release of persons or property
description: Require, demand that target releases persons or property.
usageNotes: Use this code for demands that the target release prisoners, hostages, and any confiscated property.
examples: <source>Russia</source> <verb>said</verb> on Tuesday that <target>Sudan</target> <verb>must return</verb> a Mi-26 <verb>helicopter</verb> that was captured by the Sudanese authorities last week.

name: Demand easing of economic sanctions, boycott, or embargo
description: Require, demand that target lifts or eases economic sanctions, boycott, or embargo.
usageNotes: Use this code only for 	extit{economic} sanctions, boycotts, or embargoes.
examples: The 106th <source>Inter-Parliamentary Union Conference</source> <verb>stressed</verb> the <verb>obligation</verb> of the <target>international community</target> to take immediate action to <verb>lift embargoes</verb> and other sanctions which have negatively affected children in different parts of the world.

name: Demand to allow international involvement (non-mediation)
description: Require, demand that target allow access to international actors, such as observers, humanitarian agencies, and peacekeeping forces.
usageNotes: Demands for adversaries to allow mediation are coded as 108 instead.
examples: <source>Kenzo Oshima</source>, the United Nations Emergency Relief Coordinator, <verb>demanded</verb> parties to the conflict in <target>Iraq</target> to <verb>allow humanitarian</verb> workers the freedom of movement necessary for discharging their mandate.

name: Demand de-escalation of military engagement
description: Require, demand that target stops fighting or takes measures to ease military conflict or tension.
usageNotes: Use this code for demands for ceasefires, military withdrawals, and demobilization.
examples: <source>Washington</source> along with its allies <verb>demanded</verb> that <target>Hamas</target> <verb>renounce</verb> its <verb>armed struggle</verb> against Israel.

<source>European Community</source> foreign ministers <verb>demanded</verb> the <verb>withdrawal</verb> of <target>Yugoslav</target> federal forces from Bosnia-Herzogovina on Monday calling them an occupying army, diplomats quoted an EC declaration as saying.

<source>Bosnian Serbs</source> <verb>demanded</verb> a truce with <target>Moslem</target> forces <target>in</target> east <target>Bosnia</target> before allowing U.N. aid conveys to feed starving Moslem civilians in the region.

name: Demand meeting, negotiation
description: Require, order party(ies) to meet, negotiate.
usageNotes: This event form can be initiated by either the adversaries or other third parties.
examples: <source>Yugoslavia</source> on Tuesday <verb>demanded</verb> a <verb>meeting</verb> of the <target>U.N. Security Council</target> to discuss Croatia_s military advance into the Serb-held Krajina region, describing it as ``a serious challenge to the world community.__\

name: Demand settling of dispute
description: Order parties to a conflict to reach a settlement, agreement, or resolution of conflict.
usageNotes: This event form is typically, although not exclusively, a verbal act. Note that the source for this event cannot be the adversaries themselves. When one or more parties to a conflict call for ending the conflict, that is taken to be an expression of intent on the part of that source actor and is thus coded as 037 instead.
examples: <source>Jack Straw</source> <verb>said</verb> on Friday that the <target>Sudanese government</target> and the <target>rebels in Darfur</target> <verb>must reach</verb> an <verb>agreement</verb> that stops the conflict for good before developmental assistance to the region is released.
exampleNotes: Because of the compound target, two separate events are coded.

name: Demand mediation
description: Require or demand that a third party mediates a conflict or that adversaries accept mediation of another party.
usageNotes: This event form is a verbal act. It specifically refers to demands by actors other than potential mediators; either the adversaries or a prospective mediator can be coded as the target.
examples: <source>Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak</source> <verb>said</verb> here Wednesday that the <target>US</target> <verb>must be ready to mediate</verb> between Israelis and Palestinians as soon as the Israeli elections of January 28 are finalized.

name: Disapprove, not specified below
description: Express disapprovals, objections, and complaints not otherwise specified.
usageNotes: This residual category is not coded except when distinctions among codes 111-116 cannot be made. Disapprovals are typically verbal events.
examples: On Tuesday, <source>Nigerian junior foreign minister Dubem Oniya</source> <verb>summoned</verb> <target>Niger_s ambassador Brah Mohamane</target> <verb>to complain</verb> of inaction over the gangs.

name: Criticize or denounce
description: Condemn, decry a policy or an action; criticize, defame, denigrate responsible parties.
examples: <source>Albania</source> on Friday <verb>denounced</verb> as an ugly crime <target>Yugoslavia</target>_s suppression of ethnic Albanian unrest in the southern Yugoslav province of Kosovo.

name: Accuse, not specified below
description: Charge, blame, incriminate for allegations not otherwise specified.
usageNotes: This event category contains sub-forms for more detailed coding whenever possible. 	extit{Note that events coded under 112 are allegation made by actors and do not in any way imply that the alleged events have taken place}.
examples: <source>Zimbabwean Prime Minister Robert Mugabe</source> today <verb>accused</verb> the <target>United States</target> of restoring the blackmail in the negotiations on independence for Namibia.

name: Accuse of crime, corruption
description: Allege, charge the target with, or blame for engaging in crime or corruption.
examples: Ousted president <target>Jean-Bertrand Aristide</target> <verb>has been accused</verb> of <verb>misusing</verb> up to US \$50 million (\$73 million) in <verb>public funds</verb>, much of it believed to have been embezzled, by current <source>Haitian government</source> officials.

name: Accuse of human rights abuses
description: Allege, charge the target with, or blame for human rights violations, such as arbitrary detentions for prosecutions, torture, and slavery.
examples: Human rights watchdog <source>Amnesty International</source> <verb>accused</verb>  the <target>United States</target> of <verb>violating human rights</verb>, ignoring international law and sending a ``permissive signal to abusive governments__.

name: Accuse of aggression
description: Allege, charge the target with, or blame for initiating hostilities or engaging in questionable or unjustifiable military actions such as violations of ceasefire.
usageNotes: If the nature of the military action in question relates to human rights abuses or war crimes, they should be coded elsewhere within this category.
examples: The <source>Sudanese government</source> has <verb>accused</verb> <target>Darfur rebels</target> of <verb>violating</verb> a month-old <verb>ceasefire</verb>, a member of the Chadian team trying to broker a peace pact has said.

<source>Palestinians</source> <verb>blamed</verb> <target>Israel</target> <verb>for</verb> the <verb>bombing</verb> of Raed Karmi in the West Bank City of Tulkarm, which has set off a renewed wave of violence.

name: Accuse of war crimes
description: Allege, charge the target with, or blame for participation in war crimes/
examples: <target>Kosovo_s prime minister</target> <verb>has been indicted by</verb> the <source>U.N. war crimes court</source> for his alleged part in <verb>atrocities during</verb> the <verb>fight</verb> against Serb forces and will resign.

name: Accuse of espionage, treason
description: Allege, charge the target with, or blame for spying, espionage, or treason.
examples: A <target>Christian missionary from Calgary</target> <verb>was arrested in</verb> <source>Lebanon</source> for <verb>collaborating</verb> with Israel, according to the Canadian Press. \

<source>Nigerian authorities</source> <verb>jailed</verb> 52 members of the banned <target>Movement for the Actualization of the Sovereign State of Biafra</target> (MASSOB) on <verb>allegations</verb> of <verb>treason</verb> for playing in a youth football tournament in Lagos.

name: Rally opposition against
description: Mobilize other parties against the target.
usageNotes: This event form is typically, although not exclusively, a verbal act. Use this event form to code instances where one party (the source) solicits third parties to express disapproval of, protest against, or punish another party (the target). Note that only diplomatic solicitations---not military mobilizations---should be coded here.
examples: An <source>official Syrian newspaper</source> <verb>called</verb> Thursday on Arabs to <verb>unite</verb> and ``mobilize__ <verb>against</verb> <target>Israeli right-winger Ariel Sharon</target>, who has vowed not to return the Golan Heights to Syria if he is elected prime minister February 4.
<source>Archbishop Desmond Tutu</source> on Sunday <verb>called for sanctions against</verb> <target>Nigeria</target> in the wake of the execution of Ken Saro-Wiwa.

name: Complain officially
description: Written and institutionalized protests, appeals, and all petition drives and recalls.
examples: <source>Yugoslavia</source> <verb>lodged</verb> an <verb>official protest</verb> with <target>Albania</target> today, charging its neighbor with supporting dissidents here in what is said was tantamount to inciting revolution.
<source>Lebanon</source> <verb>complained to the United Nations</verb> on Tuesday over two <target>Israeli</target> air raids last Friday in which it said 20 people were killed or wounded.

name: Bring lawsuit against
description: Sue, file civil or criminal lawsuit at domestic or international courts.
usageNotes: Source must be the plaintiff or the state, and target must be the defendant.
examples: A <source>Saudi businessman</source> <verb>is suing</verb> the <target>United States</target> for damages to his pharmaceutical plant which were caused by a missile attack in August, his American lawyer said.

name: Find guilty or liable (legally)
description: Find guilty or liable at a court of law.
usageNotes: Source must be the court in question, which could be domestic or international, and target must be the defendant. This event form refers typically to rulings against non-individuals, where imprisonment is not an issue. When individuals are found guilty and are therefore detained, use 173 instead.
examples: A <verb>European court</verb> <verb>convicted</verb> <target>Turkey</target> of "inhuman acts" Thursday for destroying the home of a Kurdish citizen in the country_s southeast.

name: Reject, not specified below
description: All rejections and refusals not otherwise specified.
usageNotes: This residual category is not coded except when distinctions among codes 121-129 cannot be made. All rejections coded under this category should imply refusals to cooperate or yield in some way.
examples: The <source>Palestinians</source> <verb>reject proposed</verb> <target>Israeli</target> <verb>changes</verb> to the Wye River land-for-security deal, chief Palestinian negotiator Saeb Erakat said.

name: Reject material cooperation, not specified below
description: Refuse to engage in or expand material exchange.
usageNotes: This category contains sub-forms for more detailed coding whenever possible. Refusals to provide unilateral material assistance---not mutual exchange---are coded as 122 instead. Note the difference between refusing to establish or expand material cooperation and reducing or eliminating existing ties (category 16).
examples: <source>Yemen</source> has <verb>rejected</verb> a <target>U.S.</target> <verb>request</verb> to <verb>interrogate</verb> detainees held after the escape of 23 al-Qaida prisoners, a security official said Tuesday.

name: Reject economic cooperation
description: Refuse to engage in or expand economic ties.
usageNotes: Use this code for rejections of mutual economic exchange, such as trade and investment; rejection to provide financial aid (or cancel debt) is coded as 1221 instead.
examples: <source>Bangladesh</source> has once again outright <verb>rejected</verb> an <target>Indian</target> <verb>proposal</verb> for signing <verb>Free Trade</verb> Agreement (FTA) with her, urging the counterpart to sign the proposed South Asia Free Trade Agreement (SAFTA) instead.

name: Reject military cooperation
description: Refuse to engage in or expand military ties.
usageNotes: Use this code for rejections of mutual military exchange; rejection to provide military aid is coded as 1222 instead.
examples: <source>South Korea</source> has <verb>rejected</verb> <target>North Korea</target>_s consistent <verb>demand</verb> to <verb>sever</verb> a decades-long <verb>military alliance</verb> with Washington, which keeps troops here under a mutual defense pact.

name: Reject judicial cooperation
description: Refuse to engage in or expand cooperation in judicial matters.
usageNotes: Use this code when the source actor refuses to cooperate in extraditions or other matters pertaining to legal proceedings.
examples: <source>Yugoslavia</source> on Thursday flatly <verb>rejected</verb> an <target>Australian</target> ultimatum to <verb>handover</verb> a <verb>guard</verb> involved in a shooting in front of the Yugoslav consulate in Sydney.

name: Reject intelligence cooperation
description: Refuse to engage in or expand cooperation in intelligence or information sharing.
usageNotes: Use this code when the source actor refuses to investigate or share information.
examples: The <source>UN</source> on Tuesday <verb>imposed</verb> a de facto <verb>information blackout</verb> on the withdrawal, collection and monitoring of heavy weapons around <target>Sarajevo</target>.

name: Reject request or demand for material aid, not specified below
description: Refuse to extend material aid not otherwise specified.
usageNotes: Use this event form to code refusals to provide material assistance. Use sub-categories whenever possible.

name: Reject request for economic aid
description: Refuse to extend financial assistance.
examples: <source>Bonn</source> <verb>rejected</verb> recent <verb>calls</verb> by <target>East Germany_s Communist rulers</target> for immediate <verb>economic aid</verb>, saying it was withholding it until a democratically-elected government takes over.

name: Reject request for military aid
description: Refuse to extend military assistance.
examples: The <source>Turkish government</source> has <verb>refused</verb> to commit to any direct <verb>assistance</verb> to the <target>US</target>-led <verb>war</verb> against Iraq, citing domestic opposition.

name: Reject request for humanitarian aid
description: Refuse to extend humanitarian assistance.
usageNotes: Refusals to provide shelter or refuge should also be coded here. When source refuses to grant humanitarian agencies access (instead of refusing to provide assistance itself), 1245 should be used instead.
examples: <source>Syria</source> <verb>says</verb> it <verb>will not accept</verb> any more <verb>refugees</verb> if war starts in Iraq.

name: Reject request for military protection or peacekeeping
description: Refuse to provide peacekeeping forces or other form of military protection.
usageNotes: Refusals by prospective providers of protection and peacekeeping should be coded here; refusals by adversaries to grant access to peacekeepers should be coded as 1245 instead.
examples: The <source>United Nations</source> on Tuesday <verb>rejected</verb> a call for its <verb>peacekeeping forces to be deployed</verb> in <target>East Timor</target>.

<source>Pakistan</source>, a key U.S. ally in the war against terrorism, has <verb>refused</verb> to <verb>deploy peacekeepers</verb> in <target>Iraq</target> and has urged its citizens to avoid coming here.

name: Reject request or demand for political reform, not specified below
description: Refuse to institute political change not otherwise specified.
usageNotes: If the reform in question clearly constitutes some form of concession or yielding by the source, such as the easing of existing administrative sanctions, a more appropriate code might be found under 124 (_Refuse to yield_). Actors requesting the demand or those (the country or the people) that will be affected by the rejection should be coded as target depending on availability of information in the lead.
examples: The <source>US</source> on Thursday <verb>rejected calls</verb> by <target>Kofi Annan</target>, UN secretary-general, to <verb>adopt</verb> far-reaching United Nations <verb>reforms</verb> as a comprehensive package.

name: Reject request to change leadership
description: Refuse to change leadership or relinquish power.
usageNotes: Rejections to resign or hand over power, as well as to hold elections that might open the way for change in leadership, are coded here. Note that while refusals to undertake other forms of yielding are coded under 124, refusals to give up power are coded here.
examples: <source>Vice-President Moody Awori</source> has <verb>declined to resign</verb> despite growing pressure by the <target>Kenya Anti-Corruption Commision</target> after he was implicated in a major scandal.

name: Reject request to change policy
description: Refuse to change a given policy.
usageNotes: Use this code for refusals to acquiesce to demands for policy change---political, economic, military, social, or otherwise. If the policy change in question clearly represents a form of yielding, the appropriate code under 124 should be used instead.

name: Reject request for rights
description: Refuse to provide or respect social, political, economic or other rights and freedoms.
usageNotes: If it is clear from the lead that by rejecting certain rights the source is in fact refusing to yield or concede, the event might be better coded under 124.
examples: <source>Ankara_s \c Cankaya district administration</source> has <verb>denied land allocation</verb> for the construction of an <target>Alevite</target> temple, Cemevi, in the district.

name: Reject request for change in institutions, regime
description: Refuse to make fundamental political changes, such as moving from one type of a political system to another and reforming political institutions or key laws.
usageNotes: Note the difference between institutional/regime changes and policy reforms.
examples: In what has been described as a policy u-turn, <source>President Levy Mwanawasa</source> has <verb>reneged</verb> on his <verb>commitment</verb> to the <target>Zambian people</target> for holding elections under a <verb>new constitution</verb>.

name: Refuse to yield, not specified below
description: Reject requests, refuse, or decline to yield not otherwise specified.
usageNotes: This category contains sub-forms for more detailed coding whenever possible.

name: Refuse to ease administrative sanctions
description: Reject requests, refuse or decline to ease administrative sanctions, such as censorship, curfew, state of emergency, and martial law.
examples: Despite warnings of starvation by humanitarian agencies, the <source>Israeli government</source> is <verb>refusing</verb> to <verb>lift</verb> the <verb>curfew</verb> on <target>Palestinians living in the West Bank and Gaza</target>.

name: Refuse to ease popular dissent
description: Reject requests, refuse, or decline to reduce or stop political protest activities, such as demonstrations and rallies.
examples: Around 1,800 of 2,200 <source>Serbian teachers</source> <verb>will not end</verb> their <verb>strike</verb> unless their demands for wage increases are met by textcolorblueBelgrade, a union official announced after three weeks of striking.

name: Refuse to release persons or property
description: Reject requests, refuse, or decline to release or return persons or property.
usageNotes: Refusals to release or exchange prisoners and hostages, as well as to return previously confiscated properties, are coded here.
examples: The <source>U.S.</source> <verb>said</verb> it would <verb>not meet</verb> hostage-takers <verb>demands</verb> to <verb>release</verb> prisoners in <target>Iraq</target>, including a number of females.
exampleNotes: In an ideal scenario, the identity of the hostage-takers would have been codeable here.

name: Refuse to ease economic sanctions, boycott, or embargo
description: Reject requests, refuse, or decline to reduce or eliminate economic sanctions, boycotts, or embargoes.
usageNotes: Use this code only for 	extit{economic} sanctions, boycotts, or embargoes.
examples: <source>US authorities</source> <verb>said</verb> yesterday that <verb>removing</verb> the <verb>sanctions</verb> on <target>Burma</target> is currently <verb>out of the question</verb> as that would reward the regime for doing nothing.

name: Refuse to allow international involvement (non-mediation)
description: Reject requests, refuse or decline to allow access to international actors such as observers, humanitarian agencies, and peacekeeping forces.
usageNotes: Prospective peacekeepers, observers, etc. are coded as targets.
examples: The <source>UNITA militarist wing</source> <verb>refused</verb> to <verb>allow</verb> <target>United Nations</target> planes to land and <verb>evacuate</verb> 15 of its observers who were taken hostage, the United Nations Observer Mission in Angola (MONUA) said.
<source>Beirut</source> again <verb>rejected</verb> Thursday a <target>United Nations</target> <verb>appeal</verb> for <verb>deploying</verb> army <verb>troops</verb> along its borders with Israel.

name: Refuse to de-escalate military engagement
description: Reject requests, refuse, or decline to stop fighting or take measures to ease military conflict or tension.
usageNotes: Use this code for rejections of ceasefires, military withdrawals, and demobilization.
examples: <source>Iran_s religious leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini</source> today <verb>rejected</verb> <target>Iraqi President Saddam Hussein</target>_s <verb>proposal</verb> for a <verb>cease-fire</verb> during the Moslem holy month of Ramadan.

<source>Rebels in the Ivory Coast</source> on Wednesday <verb>dismissed</verb> an <verb>appeal</verb> from <target>President Laurent Gbago</target> to <verb>lay down</verb> their <verb>arms</verb>, saying they had lost all trust in the government they rose up against on September 19.

name: Reject proposal to meet, discuss, negotiate
description: Refuse to meet, discuss, or negotiate.
usageNotes: Note that specific refusals to accept involvement of mediators or refusals to meet with mediators are coded as 126 instead.
examples: <source>Israeli President Moshe Katsav</source> has <verb>refused to meet</verb> <target>Jordan_s</target> visiting <target>King Abdullah II</target> in Tel Aviv, saying he would only welcome him in Jerusalem, his office said Tuesday.

The radical <source>Palestinian Islamic Jihad</source> movement <verb>rejected</verb> an invitation to attend a <verb>meeting</verb> next week of <target>Palestinian</target> factions to debate plans for independence from Israel, the group said Wednesday.

<source>Pakistan President Mohammad Zia-Ul-Haq</source> today <verb>rejected</verb> a fresh <verb>offer</verb> from <target>Afganistan</target> for direct <verb>talks</verb> between the two neighbors.

name: Reject mediation
description: Refuse involvement of mediators or mediation initiatives.
usageNotes: The target for this event should be the potential mediators.
examples: <source>Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat</source> Wednesday <verb>rejected</verb> a <target>US</target> <verb>offer</verb> to <verb>host</verb> a <verb>summit</verb> in mid-July to hammer out a framework agreement for peace between the Israelis and the Palestinians.
<source>Israel</source> is <verb>opposed</verb> to <target>French</target> <verb>mediation</verb> in peace negotiations with Syria, a close aide to Prime Minister Ehud Barak said Wednesday.

name: Reject plan, agreement to settle dispute
description: Reject a proposal or request for a final, comprehensive settlement, peace proposal, or resolution.
usageNotes: This event form refers typically, although not exclusively, to written and/or formal proposals of comprehensive settlements that seek to resolve a conflict. The target should be the opponent with whom the source is involved in a conflict.
examples: <source>Ivory Coast rebels</source> on Friday again <verb>rejected</verb> a <target>west African</target> <verb>peace plan</verb>, and said they also opposed the deployment of a regional peacekeeping force until their political demands are met.

Newly appointed <source>Palestinian Prime Minister Ismail Haniyeh</source> has <verb>refused</verb> to respond to a <verb>demand</verb> from the US President to adhere to interim <verb>peace deals</verb> reached with <target>Israel</target>.

name: Defy norms, law
description: Disobey, challenge, or resist laws or norms.
usageNotes: This event category covers both civilian disobedience and official defiance.
examples: The republic of <source>Slovenia</source> <verb>defied</verb> <target>Yugoslav</target> federal <verb>authority</verb> on Wednesday and was set to declare its right to secede from the country.
A <source>newspaper based in Christian east Beirut</source> has <verb>violated</verb> a <verb>ban</verb> by <target>General Michel Aoun</target> and described his rival Elias Hrawi as president.

name: Veto
description: Refuse to assent or formally reject legislative proposal, recommendation, or resolution.
examples: The <source>United States</source> on Wednesday <verb>vetoed</verb> a <target>Security Council</target> resolution censuring as a violation of international law its military sweep of the Nicaraguan ambassador_s home in Panama on December 29.

name: Threaten, not specified below
description: All threats, coercive or forceful warnings with serious potential repercussions, not otherwise specified.
usageNotes: Threats are typically verbal acts. This residual category is not coded except when distinctions among codes 131-139 cannot be made. When any conflictual behavior is forecasted using future tense, it is treated as a ``threat__ (e.g. _will attack_ is coded as _Threaten to attack_).
examples: <source>President Reagan</source> has <verb>threatened</verb> further action against the <target>Soviet Union</target> in an international television program beamed by satellite to more than 50 countries.

name: Threaten non-force, not specified below
description: All non-force threats not otherwise specified.
usageNotes: This event form is a verbal act. It contains sub-forms for more detailed coding whenever possible. When non-force threats are actually carried out codes 160-166 should be used instead. Threats of administrative sanctions, such as bans or curfews, should be coded under 132.
examples: <source>Iran</source> on Tuesday <verb>threatened</verb> to <verb>cut off electricity</verb> to the autonomous <target>Azerbaijani republic of Nakhichevan</target> over non-payment of bills, the official IRNA news agency reported.

name: Threaten to reduce or stop aid
description: Threaten to reduce or stop providing material aid.
usageNotes: Use this code for threats to reduce or eliminate provision of material assistance---economic, military, humanitarian, and peacekeeping.
examples: <source>African states</source> today <verb>announced</verb> that they <verb>will withdraw</verb> their <verb>peacekeeping</verb> force from <target>Chad</target> unless President Goukouni Oueddei arranged a ceasefire with rebels fighting to topple his government and held elections within four months.

name: Threaten to boycott, embargo, or sanction
description: Threaten to restrict normal economic interactions by imposing sanctions, boycotts, or embargoes.
usageNotes: Use this code for the imposition of restrictions or restraints on economic exchange, typically on commerce and similar transactions as a way to protest or punish the target.
examples: A <source>French minister</source> <verb>threatened</verb> today to impose <verb>import restrictions</verb> against <target>West German</target> goods today as the leaders of the two countries sought to ease tensions in Franco-German relations.

name: Threaten to reduce or break relations
description: Threaten to reduce or formally sever ties.
usageNotes: Non-force threats to declare independence, resign, withdraw diplomats, reduce or break diplomatic ties, etc. are all coded here.
examples: The <source>Azerbaijani parliament</source> <verb>threatened</verb> on Monday to <verb>secede</verb> from the <target>Soviet Union</target> unless the Kremlin withdrew its troops from the republic.

<source>Pakistan</source> today <verb>threatened</verb> to <verb>break</verb> off diplomatic <verb>relations</verb> with <target>Zaire</target> and <target>Costa Rica</target> over their ties with Israel on the eve of a visit here by Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO) Chairman Yasser Arafat.
<source>Palestinian leaders</source> <verb>said</verb> they <verb>would boycott all</verb> official <verb>contact</verb> with the <target>United States</target>.
exampleNotes: Because of the compound target, two events are coded in this example.

name: Threaten with administrative sanctions, not specified below
description: Threaten to impose or expand non-force administrative restrictions and penalties not otherwise specified.
usageNotes: Use sub-categories for more detailed coding whenever possible.
examples: <source>Greece</source>, like most other existing members, <verb>plans</verb> to <verb>impose restrictions</verb> on its <verb>labour</verb> market for <target>new EU members</target> for at least two years from 1 May.

name: Threaten with restrictions on political freedoms
description: Threaten to impose or expand restrictions on fundamental freedoms, such as freedoms of speech, expression, and assembly.
usageNotes: Note that if a threat indicates potential use of coercive repressive tactics as a way of enforcing the restrictions in question, 137 should be used instead.
examples: <source>Israel</source> <verb>threatened</verb> to <verb>ban voting</verb> in <target>East Jerusalem</target> if Hamas, which advocates Israel_s destruction, ran in the election.

name: Threaten to ban political parties or politicians
description: Threaten to ban political activities of particular parties or individuals.
usageNotes: If the target is being threatened with imprisonment or other measures of repression, 137 should be used instead.
examples: <source>Israel_s Cabinet</source> <verb>met</verb> Sunday and <verb>decided</verb> to approve a plan that will <verb>not allow candidates from</verb> the militant group <target>Hamas</target> on the ballots there.
<source>President Yoweri Museveni</source> has <verb>threatened</verb> to <verb>ban</verb> <target>Ugandan</target> <verb>opposition candidates</verb> from participating in the upcoming elections.

name: Threaten to impose curfew
description: Threaten to enforce a deadline beyond which inhabitants of an area are not permitted to be on the streets or in public places.
examples: <source>President Laurent Gbagbo</source> <verb>announced</verb> on Sunday that he <verb>will extend</verb> the night-time <verb>curfew</verb> in <target>Algiers</target> in response to recent unrest within the city.
<source>President Abdelaziz Bouteflicka</source> <verb>threatened</verb> to <verb>institute</verb> a <verb>curfew</verb> in <target>Algiers</target> in response to recent unrest within the city.
exampleNotes: Note that the future tense used in the lead implies a threat.

name: Threaten to impose state of emergency or martial law
description: Threaten with suspending certain given rights or the whole constitution by imposing state of emergency or military rule.
examples: <source>Iraq_s interim government</source> <verb>announced</verb> that it is <verb>prepared</verb> to <verb>impose martial law</verb> as street battles raged in central <target>Baghdad</target> between insurgents and security forces.

name: Threaten political dissent
description: Threaten to mobilize or engage in actions of political dissent such as protest demonstrations, hunger strikes, strikes or boycotts, physical obstructions into buildings or areas, and riots.
examples: Radical <source>French farmers</source> said on Friday they <verb>would blockade</verb> <target>Paris</target> from Monday night to demand an end to the European Community_s drastic farm reform.

<source>Druze inhabitants of the Syrian Golan Heights</source> <verb>threatened</verb> today to hold a <verb>general strike</verb> unless <target>Israel</target> rescinded its annexation of the region within 10 days.

name: Threaten to halt negotiations
description: Threaten to break-up or withdraw from discussion, negotiation, or meeting.
usageNotes: Use this code for threats and warnings by source actors to stop negotiations, typically presented as protests against particular actions or policies of target actors.
examples: The <source>Soviet Union</source> has <verb>threatened</verb> to <verb>stop negotiations</verb> to reduce long-range nuclear weapons if the <target>United States</target> goes ahead with the planned deployment of new medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe, the Washington Post reported today.

name: Threaten to halt mediation
description: Threaten to stop mediation activities.
usageNotes: This event form is a verbal act. Use this event form to code threats and warnings by source actors---mediators or adversaries---to stop mediating or engaging in mediated talks.
examples: The <source>European Community</source> <verb>may halt mediation</verb> efforts among <target>Yugoslavia</target>_s feuding republics <verb>if</verb> cooperation by all parties founders, Dutch Foreign Minister Hans Van den Broek said on Tuesday.

name: Threaten to halt international involvement (non-mediation)
description: Threaten to reduce or stop international intervention by expelling or withdrawing observers, humanitarian agencies, peacekeepers, etc.
usageNotes: Threats by international agencies to withdraw their involvement as well as threats by host countries to expel such actors are coded here. Note that mediation related threats are coded as 135 instead.
examples: <source>U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan</source> <verb>announced</verb> on Monday that he <verb>will withdraw</verb> weapons <verb>inspectors</verb> and <verb>humanitarian</verb> workers from <target>Iraq</target>.
exampleNotes: Future tense in the lead indicates threat (i.e. it has not yet taken place).

name: Threaten with repression
description: Threaten dissidents with forcible subjugation.
usageNotes: Threats to imprison as well as to use force to clamp down on opposition activities are coded here. Note that even though it might involve use of violence by police or other security forces, repression of dissidents is different from use of military force against another armed group; threats to use military force or to engage in battle are coded under 138 instead.
examples: <source>Cairo_s security chief</source> has <verb>warned</verb> that police <verb>will no longer tolerate rallies</verb> by the <target>Kifaya</target> (``Enough__) group.

name: Threaten with military force, not specified below
description: Threaten to use force not otherwise specified.
usageNotes: This event form is a verbal act and it contains sub-forms for more detailed coding whenever possible. More active expressions of threat to use force are coded under category 15.
examples: <source>Osama bin Laden_s al-Qaeda</source> terror network has <verb>threatened</verb> to deliver devastating <verb>blows</verb> to the <target>United States</target> and <target>Israel</target>, a Saudi-owned weekly reports.
exampleNotes: Because of the compound target, two events are coded.

name: Threaten blockade
description: Threaten to prevent entry into and/or exit from a territory using military measures.
usageNotes: This event form is typically a verbal act.
examples: <source>NATO</source> <verb>confirmed</verb> on Wednesday it <verb>would</verb> tighten the <verb>naval blockade</verb> of the rump <target>Yugoslav</target> state in the Adriatic with Albania_s help.

name: Threaten occupation
description: Threaten to occupy, seize control of the whole or part of a territory.
usageNotes: This event form is typically a verbal act and is distinct from 192, which refers to military occupations that have been or are being carried out.
examples: <source>Ethnic Albanians</source> <verb>have sworn to</verb> fight until they <verb>gain control</verb> of villages near <target>Macedonia</target>_s border with Kosovo, Macedonian officials said Wednesday.

name: Threaten unconventional attack
description: Threaten to use unconventional violence, including terrorist activities.
usageNotes: This event form is typically a verbal act and is distinct from unconventional attacks that are actually carried out (category 18).
examples: The <source>Hamas</source> <verb>threatened</verb> Monday to resume <verb>terrorist activities</verb> in <target>Israel</target> in an escalation of the intifada (uprising).

name: Threaten conventional attack
description: Threaten to attack, use conventional weapons against a party.
usageNotes: This event form is typically a verbal act.
examples: <source>Iran</source> today <verb>threatened</verb> to launch a new <verb>military offensive</verb> in its Gulf war with <target>Iraq</target> unless Baghdad accepted its conditions for ending the 28-month-old conflict.

<source>Iran</source> <verb>threatened</verb> to <verb>shell</verb> <target>Iraqi</target> towns today in retaliation for an air raid on the southern city of Susangerd where, it said, 100 people were killed.

name: Threaten unconventional mass violence
description: Threaten to use force potentially affecting large masses of people, including the use of weapons of mass destruction (nuclear or chemical-biological-radiological attacks), mass expulsions or killings, as well as ethnic cleansing.
usageNotes: This event form is typically a verbal act. Use this code for threats to carry out actions best represented in cue category 20.
examples: A <source>terror group based in Trinidad</source> <verb>claims</verb> to be manufacturing <verb>chemical</verb> and <verb>biological weapons</verb> to use <verb>against</verb> the <target>United States</target> and <target>Britain</target>, according to a media report Sunday.
exampleNotes: Because of the compound target, two events are coded.

name: Give ultimatum
description: Give a final warning, ultimate demand or order.
usageNotes: This event form is typically a verbal act. Use it to code final demands, rejection of which carries the risk of some form of retaliation by the party issuing the ultimatum. Use of this code depends primarily on the terminology used by reporters---look for the word _ultimatum_, otherwise, it is simply a threat.
examples: <source>Peru</source> has <verb>issued</verb> an <verb>ultimatum</verb> to <target>Ecuador</target> to halt attacks across their disputed jungle border.

name: Engage in political dissent, not specified below.
description: All civilian demonstrations and other collective actions carried out as protests against the target actor not otherwise specified.
usageNotes: This residual category is not coded except when distinctions among codes 141-145 cannot be made. Note that any form of civilian individual or collective action that is undertaken as a symbol of support---rather than protest---for the target actor should be coded elsewhere (potentially under category 05).
examples: The <source>Homeland Union</source> (Conservatives) <verb>began collecting signatures</verb> in part of a drive to convince the <target>Lithuanian Parliament</target> to <verb>amend</verb> the <verb>constitution</verb> so that same-sex marriages are banned.

name: Demonstrate or rally, not specified below
description: Dissent collectively, publicly show negative feelings or opinions; rally, gather to protest a policy, action, or actor(s).
usageNotes: Use sub-categories if demands of protesters are known and codeable. The target for this event form is the party that the protest is directed against; the location of a demonstration sometimes represents the identity of the target.
examples: Up to 100 <source>ethnic Albanians</source> <verb>demonstrated</verb> on Tuesday in the <target>Yugoslav province of Kosovo</target>, where 24 people were killed in nationalist riots last March, Belgrade radio said.

name: Demonstrate or rally for leadership change
description: Dissent collectively, gather, or rally demanding leadership change.
usageNotes: Target should be the actor who is expected to relinquish power. Demonstrations that demand new elections should also be coded here.
examples: Angry activists from the defeated <source>Fatah Party</source> have <verb>staged rallies</verb> in the Gaza Strip <verb>against</verb> the party_s leader <target>Mahmoud Abbas</target>, saying he must resign.

name: Demonstrate or rally for policy change
description: Dissent collectively, gather, or rally demanding policy change.
usageNotes: Use this code when demonstrators demand specific policy changes or unspecified political reforms.
examples: Tens of thousands of university <source>students throughout Indonesia</source> <verb>staged</verb> mass <verb>demonstrations</verb> Saturday to <verb>demand political reforms</verb> by <target>President Suharto</target>_s government.

name: Demonstrate for rights
description: Dissent collectively, gather, or rally demanding political, social, economic, or other rights.
usageNotes: Use this code for demonstrations that demand new rights or protest the violation of existing ones.
examples: Thousands of <source>Nigerians</source> from throughout the country <verb>were converging</verb> Thursday for a <verb>rally</verb> in Lagos to <verb>protest</verb> the <verb>rights violations</verb> under the recently imposed Sharia law by <target>Islamic fundamentalists</target> in the northern districts.

name: Demonstrate for change in institutions, regime
description: Dissent collectively, gather, or rally demanding major institutional, constitutional, or regime change.
usageNotes: Note the difference between institutional/constitutional changes and policy reforms. Demonstrations that call for independence or autonomy essentially demand major changes to the whole system and are hence coded here.
examples: Thousands of <source>Iraqi Kurds</source> <verb>demonstrated</verb> in the northern city of Kirkuk on Sunday <verb>calling for independence</verb> from <target>Iraq</target>, witnesses said.

name: Conduct hunger strike, not specified below
description: Protest by refusing to eat until certain demands are met, not further specified.
usageNotes: Use sub-categories if demands of protesters are known and codeable. The target for this event form is the party against which the hunger strikers protest.
examples: Up to 1,000 <source>ethnic Turks</source> <verb>began</verb> a <verb>hunger strike</verb> on Monday to protest against <target>Sweden</target>_s decision to send them back to Bulgaria, where they say they face imprisonment, homelessness and persecution.

name: Conduct hunger strike for leadership change
description: Refuse to eat until demands for leadership change are met.
usageNotes: Target should be the actor who is expected to relinquish power. Hunger strikes that demand new elections should also be coded here.
examples: <source>Islamic fundamentalists</source> <verb>continued</verb> their <verb>hunger strike</verb> to <verb>demand</verb> the <verb>resignation</verb> of <target>Algerian President Ahmed Ben Bella</target>.

name: Conduct hunger strike for policy change
description: Refuse to eat until demands for policy reform are met.
usageNotes: Use this code when protesters demand specific policy changes or unspecified political reforms.
examples: A member of the <source>Syrian parliament</source>, Mohammed Mamoun, <verb>started</verb> a <verb>hunger strike</verb> yesterday to <verb>protest</verb> <target>President Assad</target>_s <verb>failure</verb> to usher in meaningful political <verb>reforms</verb>.

name: Conduct hunger strike for rights
description: Refuse to eat until demands for political, social, economic, or other rights are met.
usageNotes: Use this code for hunger strikes that demand new rights or protest the violation of existing ones.
examples: <source>Algerian landowners</source> <verb>began</verb> a <verb>hunger strike</verb> outside Parliament to <verb>demand</verb> the <verb>return of property</verb> seized by <target>Algerian government forces</target> in the 1970s, APS news agency said.

<source>Salaheddine Sidhoum</source>, Algeria_s leading human rights activist, <verb>staged</verb> a 24-hour <verb>hunger strike</verb> in prison on Sunday in <verb>protest</verb> against the widespread <verb>human rights violations</verb> by <target>Algerian security forces</target>, his lawyer said on Tuesday.

name: Conduct hunger strike for change in institutions, regime
description: Refuse to eat until demands for major institutional, constitutional, or regime change.
usageNotes: Note the difference between institutional/constitutional changes and policy reforms. Hunger strikes that call for independence or autonomy essentially demand major changes to the whole system and are hence coded here.
examples: A group of <source>Chenchen refugees</source> are <verb>continuing</verb> a <verb>hunger strike</verb> in protest of the <target>Russian government</target>_s refusal to <verb>accept</verb> the <verb>independence</verb> of Chechnya.

name: Conduct strike or boycott, not specified below
description: Protest by refusing to work or cooperate until certain demands are met, not specified further.
usageNotes: Use sub-categories if demands of protesters are known and codeable. The target for this event form is the party against which the hunger strikers protest. This event form does not refer to military strikes, which are coded under category 19 instead.
examples: <source>Palestinians of the Israeli-occupied West Bank</source> <verb>shunned work</verb> on Monday <verb>to protest</verb> at settlement of <target>Soviet Jewish immigrants</target> on Arab land.

name: Conduct strike or boycott for leadership change
description: Refuse to work or cooperate until demands for leadership change are met.
usageNotes: Target should be the actor who is expected to relinquish power. Strikes or boycotts that demand new elections should also be coded here.
examples: The <source>fundamentalist Umma (Nation) party</source> has <verb>said</verb> it <verb>will boycott</verb> <target>Algeria</target>_s first multi-party elections <verb>unless</verb> the president agrees to <verb>step down</verb>.
exampleNotes: Ideally the Algerian president would have been coded as the target.

name: Conduct strike or boycott for policy change
description: Refuse to work or cooperate until demands for policy reform are met.
usageNotes: Use this code when protesters demand specific policy changes or unspecified political reforms.
examples: Some 500,000 workers affiliated with the <source>Serbian Workers_ Union</source> (SSS) <verb>stopped work</verb> on the first day of an open-ended <verb>strike</verb> on Monday over a controversial <verb>employment bill</verb> signed in by <target>Serbian Labour Minister Dragan Milovanovic</target>.

name: Conduct strike or boycott for rights
description: Refuse to work or cooperate until demands for political, social, economic, or other rights are met.
usageNotes: Use this code for strikes or boycotts that demand new rights or protest the violation of existing ones.
examples: Seven <source>opposition parties in Nepal</source> have <verb>organized</verb> a general <verb>strike</verb> that shut down <target>Khatmandu</target> in <verb>protest</verb> of last week_s <verb>arrest</verb> of a number of activists.

name: Conduct strike or boycott for change in institutions, regime
description: Refuse to work or cooperate until demands for major institutional, constitutional, or regime change.
usageNotes: Note the difference between institutional/constitutional changes and policy reforms. Strikes that call for independence or autonomy essentially demand major changes to the whole system and are hence coded here.

name: Obstruct passage, block, not specified below
description: Protest by blocking entry and/or exit into building or area, not otherwise specified.
usageNotes: Use sub-categories if demands of protesters are known and codeable. Use this event form to code protest activities that seek to disrupt routine and normal proceedings by blocking roads, buildings, etc. When the blockade in question includes military forces, use 191 instead.
examples: Angry <source>French paper workers</source> <verb>blocked</verb> the <target>Europe Bridge</target> spanning the Rhine from France to West Germany for more than three hours by dumping sawdust on the <verb>roadway</verb>, French border police said.

name: Obstruct passage to demand leadership change
description: Obstruct passage, block entry/exit to demand leadership change.
usageNotes: Target should be the actor who is expected to relinquish power. Obstructions that demand new elections should also be coded here.
examples: About 200 <source>supporters of former President Ahmed Ben Bella</source> <verb>blocked roads</verb> in the capital city of <target>Algiers</target> <verb>demanding</verb> that he be <verb>reinstated as leader</verb> of the Algerian government.

<source>Rebels in the Ivory Coast</source> on Tuesday <verb>blocked transport</verb> into Abidjan as they continued their effort <verb>to overthrow</verb> the <verb>government</verb> of <target>President Laurent Gbagbo</target>.

name: Obstruct passage to demand policy change
description: Obstruct passage, block entry/exit to demand policy reform.
usageNotes: Use this code when protesters demand specific policy changes or unspecified political reforms.
examples: Demonstrators in <source>Baghdad</source> <verb>blocked</verb> a <verb>road</verb> to show their <verb>disapproval</verb> for the <target>United States</target>_ military <verb>policies</verb>, a newspaper reported Tuesday.

name: Obstruct passage to demand rights
description: Obstruct passage, block entry/exit to demand political, social, economic, or other rights.
usageNotes: Use this code for obstructions that demand new rights or protest the violation of existing ones.
examples: Young <source>Algerians</source> <verb>blocked roads</verb> leading to the city centre on Sunday to press their <verb>demands</verb> for greater <verb>freedom</verb> and opportunities from <target>President Bouteflika</target>_s government.

name: Obstruct passage to demand change in institutions, regime
description: Obstruct passage, block entry/exit to demand major institutional, constitutional, or regime change.
